Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Coping with COVID-19: Emotion Regulation Strategy Implications for Behavior, Social Outcomes, and Well-Being

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 is producing an extraordinary set of stressors and demands. The country is facing a life-threatening health crisis and associated economic fallout. That stress is exacerbated by unexpectedness, unpredictability, contradictory and uncertain information, and low personal control. At the same time, people are asked to adopt a series of unfamiliar social distancing and hygiene behaviors in an attempt to “flatten the curve” of the coronavirus’s spread. Enacting the CDC-recommended behaviors requires both emotion regulation and effortful self-control. Research on emotion regulation – the ways people attempt to alter or change their own emotions – distinguishes among several strategies such as looking for a “silver lining” in upsetting events, reaching out for social support, intellectualizing the problem, and distraction with television and games. The coronavirus pandemic provides a unique set of circumstances in which to examine how reliance on different emotion regulation strategies predicts people’s health-related behaviors and emotional well-being given these unusual circumstances. Findings from this research will inform future public policy recommendations that encourage health-promoting behaviors in stress-related situations.

This research examines the extent to which daily use of 16 distinct emotion regulation strategies predicts adoption/maintenance of CDC-recommended social distancing, hygiene and healthy social engagement behaviors. The research also examines how these emotion regulation strategies influence various prosocial and antisocial behaviors, psychological well-being, and loneliness. For three weeks, participants complete a daily questionnaire measuring their use of specific emotion regulation techniques that day; every seventh day they also answer questions about their behavior (e.g., mask-wearing, avoiding social gatherings, technology-mediated socializing, donating money or supplies, hoarding), as well as loneliness, anxiety, and depression, during the previous week. Data analyses will ask which emotion regulation strategies, or combinations of strategies, predict the most desirable profile of behavioral and well-being outcomes. The research tests important emotion regulation theories and their applicability within the unique coronavirus pandemic context and has the potential to inform future stress-related intervention efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
People use a wide range of emotion regulation strategies for coping with stressful/distressing situations. The major goals for this project were to collect data for two studies examining use of specific emotion regulation (ER) strategies during the coronavirus pandemic, as well as their implications for predicting adoption of CDC-recommended health behaviors, and for psychological well-being.

Study 1 surveyed N = 520 research subjects, demographically representative of the U.S. population, asking them to rate how much they had used each of 17 specific strategies for coping with pandemic-associated stress/distress during the preceding 24 hours. All data were colllected in late April - early May 2020. The five most-used strategies were Distraction (e.g., by TV or games), Savoring (e.g., coffee, flowers, a pleasant vista), Exercise, Information-Seeking, and Active Coping (i.e., practical action). The five least-used strategies were Giving Up, Substance Use, Instrumental Support-Seeking, Emotional Support-Seeking, and Denial. Statistical analyses indicated that the 17 strategies formed seven broad clusters, each reflecting emphasis on a goal beyond simply reducing distress: (1) Do Something (Active Coping, Planning, Information Seeking, Detached Reappraisal); (2) Defeat (Substance Use, Give Up); (3) Exercise; (4) Denial (Denial, Distancing); (5) Prayer; (6) Positive Emotion (Distraction, Savoring, Positive Reappraisal, Humor); and (7) Social Connection (Instrumental Support Seeking, Emotional Support Seeking, Fun Socializing). These clusters of coping/emotion regulation strategies were emphasized in analyses for Study 2.

In Study 2, N = 297 research subjects completed an online questionnaire every day for 22 days during the late Spring/Summer of 2020. Subjects were recruited via Craigslist and NextDooor.com, and were demographically representative of the U.S. population in terms of gender, ethnicity, age, and income. The emotion regulation questionnaire from Study 1, as well as measures of sleep, exercise, relationship satisfaction, and consumption of high-sugar beverages and snacks, alcohol, and cigarettes were completed daily. On days 1, 8, 15, and 22, the questionnaire also included measures of CDC-recommended health behaviors (safe behavior in public, e.g., masking; hand-washing; remote socializing, e.g., via Zoom or telephone; avoiding in-person socializing; fun activities with household members) and psychological well-being (anxiety, depression, stress, and positive and negative affect). Data analyses ask whether reliance on particular categories of emotion regulation strategies (from Study 1) predicts baseline health behavior and well-being, as well as change over time in these outcomes. Health behavior appeared fixed at the start of the study; statistical analyses suggested very little change over time that could potentially be predicted by emotion regulation, or by any other predictor. However, in some associations observed on Day 1, Denial was associated with worse health behavior; Social Connection-based regulation, Positive Emotion-focused regulation, and Prayer with better health behavior; and "Do Something" regulation was associated with more hand-washing, but less healthy socializing. With respect to psychological well-being, Positive Emotion-based regulation, "Do Something" regulation, and Exercise were each generally associated with higher/increasing well-being; and Social Connection-based regulation, Defeat, and Denial with worse and declining well-being. 

Positive impacts from this project include: providing a new measure of coping/emotion regulation for future research; expanding knowledge about goals beyond distress reduction that drive people's choice of coping strategies; and identifying coping strategies that are more vs. less conducive to healthy behavior and psychological well-being during an extended period of stress. These last findings have implications for future interventions aimed at promoting healthy behavior and mental health. This project also contributed in important ways to the training and diversity of the future behavioral science and healthcare workforce. Two female graduate students were supported by this project and engaged with all aspects of study planning, data collection, analysis, and publication of findings; and a cohort of undergraduate students partcipated in study development as well. These include several trainees from underrepresented minority backgrounds. Many trainees are expected to go on to careers in behavioral science, counseling/social work, or the medical field, and will carry this educational experience with them.
